text_image_relationship.layout_style: Two columns of text with a large square miniature inserted in the left column interrupting eight lines of text; a historiated initial begins the section above the miniature; wide margins on left and right filled with a continuous vine-scroll decorated with flowers, birds, and grotesques; bottom margin hosts small narrative vignettes in line with the central axis; visual hierarchy emphasizes the miniature, then the historiated initial, then marginal scenes.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata, professional book hand with regular ruling, extensive use of abbreviations and ligatures

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf reserved for patterned background and ornamental frame, emphasizing importance of the battle; ultramarine-equivalent azurite blue used for knights’ surcoats and backgrounds to denote nobility; vermilion red applied to shields and helmet crests for visual contrast; leaf green in marginal foliage; layered application with white highlighting on drapery folds; minimal oxidation indicates stable preservation; alternating red and blue initials with gold flourishes punctuate the text.

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill pen work in dark brown ink with bold outlines and finer internal detail lines
drawing_technique.shading_method: Sparse parallel hatching in drapery folds and armor, white lead highlights for volume
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: No true linear perspective, depth implied by overlapping figures and partial architectural fragment at left of miniature

content_theme.scene_description: The miniature depicts a densely packed battle between mounted knights before a crenellated gate. Approximately nine figures occupy the space: five knights in full chain mail and conical helmets with nasal bars charge from the right, wielding lances couched under arms, their horses caparisoned in heraldic cloth. Four defenders on the left hold kite shields bearing contrasting tinctures and raise swords and spears against the onslaught. Surcoats display geometric and animal heraldry in blue, red, and gold. The gatehouse wall is rendered in grey with blue highlights, suggesting stone. The central action shows two knights locked lance-to-lance, their horses rearing. Scale is uniform; all figures are approximately the same height. Depth is suggested by overlapping bodies and the gate fragment. Armor and weapons are meticulously detailed: visored great helms, conical nasal helms, kite shields, and straight swords. Horses have embroidered caparisons with visible tailor’s patterns. Under the miniature, a red rubric announces the battle. Below the historiated initial and in the bottom margin, small processional figures on horseback and standing figures negotiate over a chest, linking text to action.

secular: mounted knight in blue surcoat with gold lion rampant, conical helm; mounted knight in red surcoat with chequered shield; two castle defenders on foot with round shields

objects: kite and round shields with heraldic devices

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum, uniformly thin, hair-side flesh smooth with visible follicle pattern, supported in a quaternion gathering; margins ruled with plummet
technical_features.preservation_condition: Vivid pigments with minimal oxidation, slight flaking of vermilion in finest lines, minor cockling at upper corners, evidence of 20th-century margin consolidation

regular ruling indentations visible under UV
confident underdrawing in brown ink visible in horse legs

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This illuminated battle scene likely originates from a mid-14th-century French chronicle produced in a secular court workshop. The richly burnished gold background and heraldic color palette reflect the high status of the commissioner, while the inclusion of detailed martial equipment aligns with contemporary interest in chivalric ideals. The sophisticated layering of azurite pigment and white lead highlights demonstrates technical mastery, and the presence of elaborate vine borders with birds suggests collaboration among specialized illuminators and border artists. Iconographically, the depiction of mounted knights engaging before a fortified gate may allude to a specific siege narrative, possibly from the Chronicle of St. Denis, intended to reinforce noble lineage through association with historic military exploits. The historiated initial and marginal vignettes indicate a multifaceted narrative strategy, using both central and peripheral imagery to support the text. Stylistically, the uniform figure scale and absence of linear perspective are characteristic of Gothic manuscript illumination in northern France, whereas the naturalistic detailing of equine anatomy points to evolving artistic conventions. Compared to the Psalter of Jeanne de Belleville, this manuscript shares the use of gold bezants and foliate scrolls but diverges in its martial subject matter. Overall, this page exemplifies the blending of historical documentation, chivalric propaganda, and artistic innovation in a high-status educational manuscript.
